Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Continuous and Interrupted Suture Techniques for Biliary-Enteric Anastomosis

Trial_Design.evidence: single-centre randomised controlled trial included 82 patients

Participants.evidence: included 82 patients scheduled for elective open BEA between January 2016 and September 2017

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to CS or IS groups

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of continuous suture (CS) versus interrupted suture (IS) techniques for biliary-enteric anastomosis (BEA)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was suture time, measured intraoperatively

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using block randomisation with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to patients and outcome assessors, but not to surgeons

Number_Randomised.evidence: Conducted at University Hospital Dresden, this single-centre randomised controlled trial included 82 patients scheduled for elective open BEA between January 2016 and September 2017

Number_Analysed.evidence: Eighty patients received the allocated intervention (41 CS, 39 IS)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The CS group had a significantly shorter suture time (median 12.0 minutes, IQR 10.0–17.0) compared to the IS group (median 22.4 minutes, IQR 15.0–28.0; OR 1.26, 95% CI 1.13 to 1.40; P < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Mortality and other adverse events were comparable between groups, with one death in the CS group due to pneumonia and multi-organ failure
